awd_titl_txt: HBCU-RISE Center for Advanced Multi-scale Computational Algorithms (AMCA)
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this award is to establish the NSF  HBCU-RISE Center for Advanced Multi-Scale Computational Algorithms (AMCA) at North Carolina A & T State University (NCA&T).Numerical modeling of many important physicochemical phenomena (atmospheric chemical transport,combustion,industrial chemically reactive flows,etc.)present an enormous challenge due to a wide range of spatial and temporal scales associated with the described phenomena and an enormous number of chemical species and reactions required for detailed desctiprion. The focus of this award is to study and enhance the performance of numerical techniques utilizing multiscale computational reduiction methods,taking advantage of the multiscale nature of the underlying physical proble.
The broader significance of the research is that it will enable the optimization of numerical solutions in many large scale  numerical problems arising in atmospheric chemical transport,combustion modeling, and  modeling of chemically reactive flows. As a result, simulation times of large scale phenomena will be shortened significantly.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF HBCU-RISE award enables us to establish the center for Advanced Multi-scale Computational Algorithms (AMCA) at North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T).

 Intellectual merit. The center has developed research and educational infrastructure in the area of advanced multi-scale numerical algorithms for computational and analytical modeling of Tropical Cyclone (TC) dynamics and Atmospheric Chemical Transport (ACT). The algorithms enable one to solve important problems in the area that are difficult or impossible to solve by using conventional numerical techniques.

 Broader Impacts. More accurate numerical simulation of global Atmospheric Chemical Transport is crucial for addressing problems and issues related to atmospheric air quality, climate forcing and greenhouse gases budget. Tropical Cyclones are considered to be one of the most lethal natural disasters that often cause multiple deaths and destructions.  That is why it is important to be able to accurately forecast their track and intensity to minimize the concomitant damages. AMCA project has enabled NCA&T to develop a new research and educational capacity in the area of scientific computing, advanced numerical and mathematical methods and their application to a variety of multi-scale physicochemical problems of practical interest. It has significantly enhanced the institutional technical and scientific capability, as well as helped to cultivate and nurture interest among minority students, leading to an integration of research and education while enhancing diversity in atmospheric science, applied mathematics and computational science.

The outcome of the AMCA project is described below.

AMCA center has developed inter-disciplinary research and educational initiative in multi-scale computational modeling in atmospheric sciences. This initiative involves research components from four NCA&T research and educational bodies: computational science component from Computational Science and Engineering (CSE) Ph.D. program, atmospheric science component from the Energy and Environmental Systems (EES) Ph.D. program and Physics department and applied mathematics component from the Mathematics department (see attached Fig 1).

AMCA center has strengthened collaboration between four research and educational divisions at NCA&T: CSE and EES doctoral programs, and Mathematics and Physics departments (see attached Fig 2). AMCA PIs, Drs. Rastigejev, Lin and Tang are the faculty at Math/EES, Phys/EES and Math departments/programs, respectively. All Doctoral and Master’s students supported by AMCA are placed either at EES or CSE programs, or in Math or Physics departments.

AMCA center has recruited and supported seven Doctoral, six Master’s students and one postdoctoral fellow, who have been actively involved into research on development and application of advanced multi-scale computational algorithms for modeling different complex atmospheric phenomena.

 AMCA project has contributed to expending the diversity in the area of computational science, applied mathematics and atmospheric science by attracting and engaging students from underrepresented minority groups to scientific research in these areas. Specifically, six out of seven Doctoral students and three out of six Master’s students have been U.S. citizens or US permanent residents. All U.S. students except two have been under-represented minority and/or female students.
